Comment: Here's a general breakdown for anyone who's uncertain:   We obviously need to wait until the midterms. We have the two special elections to fill the seats of Raúl Grijalva (Arizona's 7th district) and Sylvester Turner (Texas' 18th district), both of whom passed away this year. Of course, the bigger challenge is the Senate. 67 votes in favor of conviction are required for removal, and right now there are 45 Democrats, 2 Independents (both of whom will obviously vote for removal), and 53 Republicans. Four Democrats and Mitch McConnell have announced their retirement, so those five seats are up for grabs. 22 Republicans and 12 Democrats are running for reelection. The website [racetothewh.com](http://racetothewh.com) puts 11 of these seats in the "Safe Red" category, meaning they are almost certain to win reelection (except for McConnell's seat in Kentucky). Even if we're being as generous as possible and say that all the other seats go to Democrats and all the Democrats keep their seats, that would still be 58 Democrats and Independents to 42 Republicans. Then, it would take the convincing of nine Republicans to vote for removal.   I apologize if this post came off as wordy and disheartening, but I want to make it clear that the road isn't easy, but I think it can be done.

On one hand the author says the Liberal government gave preference to, for example, large automotive businesses instead of investing in other high-tech sectors like biotech, IT and robotics. But then on the other he says the government “preferenced” small businesses over large ones for R&D funding and tax credits. But wouldn’t the small high- tech businesses be the very home-grown businesses that would be the source of the forward-thinking Canadian industrial strategy the author initially claimed was not being pursued?  He comes off as simply looking for his own handout and bitter that other sectors or industries, and not the ones he favours, received help.  In other places, he’s frustratingly vague. In the “governance” section, for example, he doesn’t give any specifics. He just goes on about “performance politics.” But what does that mean in terms of dollars and cents? No idea.  Similarly, no idea what to make of the defence spending thing. Why is spending tax dollars there a good thing (even though it brings no direct benefit to Canadians) but spending tax dollars elsewhere on social programs like pharmacare and dental care (which Canadians actually need in their daily lives) a bad thing? Ironically, that’s what counts to me as “performance politics.”  I do agree the productivity issue is a puzzle, but I think it’s a bit more complicated than the author makes it out to be though it’s hinted at in one of the references he gives (it has to do with the global shift of manufacturing away from the developed world to other places).  I do get a kick out of the crocodile tears about stagnant worker wages though. Because we all know businesses love nothing more than to pay their employees more money, lol.
Author: AtticaBlue
